text: trance is sprung dramatically to life in
recent weeks both over Libya and now
Ivory Coast this looks to me like a
reaction possibly an overreaction by
President Nicolas Sarkozy after Francis
conspicuous failings in both Tunisia and
Egypt where it was way behind the curve
and looked like it was in bed with the
former leader of Tunisia Ben Ali and
then with Mubarak in Egypt and the
former foreign minister in France had to

contacts are with Ben Ali and it also
caused embarrassment to prime minister
feel now when it came to Libya and now
Ivory Coast and with an election looming
next year President Sarkozy decided he
wanted to be very much ahead of things
France of course has been the first to
recognize the rebels in Libya the
transitional authority in Benghazi now
an ivory coast are responding to a UN
resolution which gives it some legal
footing but not i think really would
approve one french troops have
intervened on the side of ouattara the
victor in elections last year according
to the African Union the UN and all
neutral observers to try and secure the

been resisting and is now holed up in a

this has been a very aggressive move on
France's part there was a UN motion last
Monday there's been talk of the new
responsibility to protect providing the
justification but French troops have
really taken side in Ivory Coast in
trying to force this outcome I think
this is all about Sarkozy wanting to
show that France matters France counts
that the France that we saw in Tunisia
in Egypt is not the real France but the
real France stands boldly as befits the
tradition of the revolution on the side
of human rights on the side of democracy
and on the
side of freedom how all this plays out
of course in both Libya and ivory coast
where France's intervention and the UN's
might make subsequent national
reconciliation more difficult how will
that plays out remains to be seen now
president Sarkozy does have an election
next year of course in 2012 he's
trailing so badly in the polls that some
people have suggested he shouldn't on so
I think this very vigorous intervention
in in both Libya and now Ivory Coast has
to be seen in that context
